Next, answering the question, I now request the Tathagata to explain for the bodhisattvas the profound and subtle practices, etc.

As for the five practices, although the practice of illness has been explained above to counteract afflictions, the characteristics of the practice and the sequence of the practice have not yet been explained, and now they are explained.
What are they?
One must be unfettered oneself in order to be able to untie the bonds of others, therefore the holy practices are first.
If one can untie the bonds of others, the merit is due to the four equalities, therefore the brahma practices are explained next.
The four equalities and extensive salvation require spiritual powers, and the way of spiritual powers is best in the four dhyanas, so the heavenly practices are explained next.
The spiritual way connects with beings, sometimes foolish and sometimes wise, so the practices of an infant are explained next.
If these four practices are in the stage of learning, they are called the practice of illness as an antidote to afflictions;
If they are in the stage of no-more-learning, they are called the practice of the Tathagata, because the Tathagata is able to speak and practice.

The nature of bliss is the primary cause, and the subtle practices are the contributory causes. Without these two causes and the previous arousal of the mind, how can one approach the supreme path?
This is the answer to how one can approach the supreme and unsurpassed path.
Although practices are innumerable, five are truly comprehensive.
The practice of sages illuminates with wisdom, speaking of the inner; the practice of purity uses other things to discuss the outer. With these two practices, one traverses the ten grounds.
The practice of the infant and the practice of the sick are what the skillful wisdom and expedient means manifest as being the same. This practice is only for those above the eighth ground.
Moreover, the practice of the sick is the practice of suffering. Only bodhisattvas can practice it. The two vehicles have sickness but cannot practice it, so it is called the practice of sickness.
